text: My biggest advice to people is, oftentimes the analysis paralysis of dotting every eye, crossing every tee sometimes chokes you out of opportunities. When you find something that gives you energy, just jump in with both feet.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Lenny asks Sanchan for advice on how someone starting out could follow a similar trajectory to work at incredible companies like Instagram, Airbnb, and Coinbase. Sanchan reflects on his own career path, noting that he never had a detailed plan but instead stumbled upon opportunities. He emphasizes that over-planning can prevent people from seizing opportunities when they arise.
vocabulary_highlights: dotting every eye, crossing every tee
text_ko: 제일 드리고 싶은 조언은, 모든 걸 다 맞추려고 하다 보면 분석 마비(analysis paralysis)에 걸려 기회를 놓치는 경우가 많다는 거예요. 어떤 일이 나한테 에너지를 주고 해보고 싶다는 생각이 들면, 망설이지 말고 과감히 두 발로 뛰어들어요.
text_zh: 我给大家最重要的建议就是，有时候你把每个细节都分析得过于透彻，反而会错失良机。当你发现某个事情能让你充满干劲的时候，就别犹豫了，直接全身心投入进去。
text_es: Mi mejor consejo es que muchas veces el quedarse paralizado analizando cada detalle hasta el cansancio te hace perder oportunidades increíbles. Cuando encuentres algo que te llene de energía, lánzate de cabeza sin pensarlo tanto.
key_sentence: Analysis paralysis chokes you out of opportunities; jump in with both feet.

text: You take little bets, you try them out. If they don't work out, you build rapid recovery and start to do something else. And that is the meta story connecting all the dots in my life, in all the career opportunities that I've had.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Sanchan continues explaining his career philosophy, referencing a book called 'Little Bets' that validated his approach to life. He describes how taking small risks and quickly recovering from failures has been the underlying theme throughout his career moves from aerospace engineering to startups to major tech companies.
text_ko: 작은 시도(little bets)를 해보고, 잘 안되면 빠른 회복(rapid recovery)을 마련해서 다른 걸 시도해요. 그게 제 인생과 모든 커리어 기회들을 잇는 메타 스토리(meta story)이에요.
text_zh: 你就是要小试牛刀，试着做一些小的尝试。如果不行的话，就赶紧调整过来，换个方向继续干。这其实就是我人生的主线，把我所有的职业机会都串起来的那条线。
text_es: Haces pequeñas apuestas, las pruebas. Si no funcionan, te recuperas rápido y empiezas a hacer otra cosa. Y esa es la historia que conecta todos los puntos de mi vida, en todas las oportunidades profesionales que he tenido.
key_sentence: Little bets and rapid recovery connect all the dots in my career.

text: My advice to people is go get a job which will make you the fastest learner in the field of product management. That is what will help you a lot. No course, no degree, none of those things will help. The most important thing will be how quickly can you jump in, learn the auto product management.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Lenny asks for advice on getting into product management. Sanchan explains that product management requires learning both the art (intuition, community insights) and science (data, methodology) aspects. He emphasizes that formal education can't replace hands-on experience in learning product management skills.
text_ko: 제 조언은 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management) 분야에서 가장 빨리 배우게 해주는 일을 찾으라는 거예요. 그게 정말 큰 도움이 돼요. 어떤 코스나 학위 같은 건 별로 도움이 안 돼요. 가장 중요한 건 얼마나 빨리 뛰어들어 실제 프로덕트 매니지먼트(product management)를 배우느냐예요.
text_zh: 我建议大家去找一份能让你在产品管理(product management)这个领域学得最快的工作。这个对你帮助最大。什么课程啊、学位啊，这些都没用。最关键的是你能多快上手，学会产品管理(product management)这套东西。
text_es: Mi consejo es que busquen un trabajo que los haga aprender súper rápido en el área de gestión de productos (product management). Eso es lo que realmente les va a servir un montón. Ningún curso, ningún título, nada de eso les va a ayudar tanto. Lo más importante va a ser qué tan rápido pueden meterse de lleno y aprender gestión de productos sobre la marcha.
key_sentence: Jump in quickly to learn auto product management effectively.

text: The way to think about this is let's say you want to get to a destination, whichever destination it is, you probably want to get on the faster ship. You don't want to get on a slower ship. That's one metaphor to use in your mind.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Lenny asks what people should look for when choosing a company to join to accelerate their learning and career. Sanchan uses a ship metaphor to explain how to think about company selection - you want to join companies that are moving quickly toward success because your career growth is tied to the company's trajectory.
text_ko: 이걸 생각하는 방식은, 목적지가 어디든 간에 빨리 가고 싶다면 당연히 더 빠른 배를 타고 싶을 거예요. 느린 배를 타고 싶진 않을 거고요. 머릿속에 이렇게 비유해 두면 돼요.
text_zh: 这么说吧，假设你要去一个地方，不管是哪儿，你肯定想坐快船，不会想坐慢船对吧？这就是一个很好的比喻。
text_es: La forma de verlo es así: digamos que quieres llegar a un destino, cualquiera que sea, seguramente vas a querer subirte al barco más rápido. No te vas a subir al barco más lento. Esa es una metáfora que puedes usar para entenderlo.
key_sentence: Choose the faster ship to reach your destination.

text: What I found is that at Airbnb, I learned a bunch of different things. One, I learned how to build products where software is just one part of the product. Let me explain that a little bit. The product of Airbnb isn't the app. It is a means to an end. The product of Airbnb is the memories you're going to create when you sit in that Airbnb beautiful house with your family, with your friends, and you're building those memories. That's the product. It's in real world.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Lenny asks where Sanchan learned the most in his career. Sanchan explains that Airbnb taught him the most, particularly how to build products that extend beyond software into real-world experiences. He distinguishes between pure software products and products where software enables a physical experience.
text_ko: Airbnb에서 일하면서 여러 가지를 배웠어요. 그중 하나는 소프트웨어가 프로덕트(product)의 일부에 불과한 제품을 만드는 법이에요. 좀 더 설명할게요. Airbnb의 프로덕트(product)는 앱(app)이 아니에요. 앱은 목적을 이루기 위한 수단일 뿐이에요. Airbnb의 진짜 프로덕트는 가족이나 친구들과 그 아름다운 집에 앉아 함께 만들어가는 추억이에요. 그게 바로 제품이고, 현실 세계에 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 我发现在Airbnb的时候，我学到了好多东西。首先，我学会了怎么做产品，就是软件只是产品的一部分而已。我解释一下啊。Airbnb真正的产品不是那个app，app只是个工具。Airbnb真正的产品是什么呢？是你和家人朋友一起住在那个漂亮房子里创造的美好回忆，那才是真正的产品。它存在于现实世界中。
text_es: Lo que descubrí es que en Airbnb aprendí un montón de cosas diferentes. Primero, aprendí a crear productos donde el software es solo una parte del producto. Te explico un poco mejor. El producto de Airbnb no es la app. Es un medio para conseguir algo más grande. El producto de Airbnb son los recuerdos que vas a crear cuando estés sentado en esa casa hermosa de Airbnb con tu familia, con tus amigos, construyendo esos recuerdos. Ese es el producto. Está en el mundo real.
key_sentence: The product is a means to an end: creating memories.

text: I felt like it all compressed into three years something that you will learn in 30. I definitely didn't think that is what happened, but that's what ended up happening. Luckily, everything worked out, and I'm happy to share what we did and how we navigated through that with the audience, but it was some crazy, crazy times, man.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Sanchan describes his learning experience at Airbnb, which included hypergrowth, scaling the product organization from 30-40 people to 200 people, and crisis management during COVID-19 when travel essentially stopped. He reflects on how these compressed experiences provided decades worth of learning in just three years.
vocabulary_highlights: compressed into three years something that you will learn in 30
text_ko: 30년 걸려 배울 걸 3년 만에 다 배운 기분이었어요. 분명 그렇게 될 거라고는 생각하지 않았는데, 결국 그렇게 됐어요. 다행히 모든 게 잘 풀렸고, 우리가 어떤 일을 했고 그 시기를 어떻게 헤쳐 나왔는지 청중분들과 나눌 수 있어서 기뻐요. 진짜 정신없고 미친 시간들이었어요.
text_zh: 感觉就像把30年才能学到的东西全压缩到3年里了。当时我肯定没想到会这样，但事情就是这么发生的。还好最后都挺过来了，我很愿意跟大家分享我们当时是怎么做的，怎么熬过那段时间的，但说真的，那段时间真的是太疯狂了。
text_es: Sentí como que en tres años se comprimió todo lo que normalmente aprenderías en 30. Definitivamente no pensé que eso era lo que iba a pasar, pero al final fue exactamente lo que pasó. Por suerte todo salió bien, y me da mucho gusto compartir con ustedes lo que hicimos y cómo logramos salir adelante, pero fueron tiempos súper locos, en serio.
key_sentence: Compressed into three years what you learn in 30; crazy, crazy times.

text: The real genius isn't to dot every eye, to cross every team before you get started. The real genius is, what do you do when shit goes wrong? And I believe rapid recovery is the key to success. What you do, how quickly you can recover from failure becomes really important.
speaker: Sanchan Saxena
context: Sanchan shares lessons from navigating Airbnb through the COVID-19 crisis, when the company had to lay off 1,900 employees and revenue dropped to single digits of the previous year. He explains that success isn't about perfect planning but about how quickly you can adapt and recover when unexpected challenges arise.
vocabulary_highlights: dot every eye, cross every team
text_ko: 진짜 영리함은 시작하기 전에 모든 걸 완벽하게 갖춰 놓는 게 아니에요. 진짜 영리함은 일이 잘못됐을 때 어떻게 대응하느냐예요. 저는 빠른 회복(rapid recovery)이 성공의 핵심이라고 믿어요. 무엇을 하느냐, 실패에서 얼마나 빨리 회복할 수 있느냐가 정말 중요해요.
text_zh: 真正的高手不是说一开始就把所有细节都搞得完美无缺。真正的高手是，当事情搞砸了的时候你怎么办？我觉得快速恢复(rapid recovery)才是成功的关键。你怎么做，你能多快从失败中缓过来，这个才真的重要。
text_es: La verdadera genialidad no está en tener todo perfecto desde el principio, en cuadrar cada detalle antes de empezar. La verdadera genialidad es: ¿qué haces cuando todo se va al carajo? Y yo creo que la recuperación rápida es la clave del éxito. Lo que hagas, qué tan rápido te puedas recuperar del fracaso, eso es lo que realmente importa.
key_sentence: Real genius isn't dotting every eye, but achieving rapid recovery from failure.
